author: mklement0
body:
Being able to create symlinks using relative paths is an important feature that both the `ln` utility on Unix and cmd's built-in command `mklink` on Windows support.

Currently, PowerShell invariably resolves the specified path to an _absolute path_ when a symlink is created.
(#801 brought us the ability to create symlinks to non-existing targets,  but even they are invariably resolved to an absolute path when the symlink is created).

Instead, the symlink should be defined with the target path _exactly as specified_.

Steps to reproduce (Unix)
------------------

```powershell
$null = New-Item -ItemType SymbolicLink /tmp/$PID -Target ./foo -Force
readlink /tmp/$PID
```


Expected behavior
-----------------

```
./foo
```

The symlink should be defined with the target path exactly as specified.

Actual behavior
---------------

```
/Users/jdoe/foo
```

The symlink was unexpectedly defined with an absolute path.

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.0-alpha (v6.0.0-alpha.17) on Darwin Kernel Version 16.5.0: Fri Mar  3 16:52:33 PST 2017; root:xnu-3789.51.2~3/RELEASE_X86_64
```

comments.author: elca-lan
comments.body:
Some official comment would be helpful here. I just ran into this issue and I must say, in _most_ scenarios that I have so far encountered (e.g. symlinks in git repositories) **absolute** symlinks are not exactly very helpful.

On Windows, I can still work around the issue by calling out to `cmd /C mklink /D mylink .\mytarget` but this really seems like a fairly fundamental flaw in the cmdlet.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Agreed, @elca-lan. @SteveL-MSFT, perhaps this can be marked as up-for-grabs?

On Unix-like platforms the workaround is to use `ln -s ./mytarget mylink`.

title: New-Item -ItemType SymbolicLink should support creating symlinks with relative paths
